snp5.6:5.2.eng: the principle of seclusion so that I may understand.

snp5.7:1.3.eng: “I am not able to cross the great flood.

snp5.7:1.4.comm: At Kaṭha Upaniṣad 2.17, the ultimate “support” is the syllable om.

snp5.7:1.5.eng: depending on which I may cross this flood.”

snp5.7:2.3.eng: depending on the perception ‘there is nothing’, <j>cross the flood.
snp5.7:2.3.comm: Natthīti abbreviates natthi kiñcī’ti, which marks the dimension of nothingness.

snp5.7:2.4.eng: Giving up sensual pleasures, <j>refraining from chatter,
snp5.7:2.4.comm: Niddesa explains kathāhi as either “doubts” (truncated kathaṅkathā), or “talks”. Elsewhere (paṭi)virato is commonly used with speech and never, to my knowledge, with doubt.

snp5.7:2.5.eng: watch day and night for the ending of craving.”

snp5.7:3.1.eng: “One who is free of desire for sensual pleasuress,”

snp5.7:3.3.eng: “depending on nothingness, all else left behind,

snp5.7:3.4.eng: freed in the ultimate liberation of perception:
snp5.7:3.4.comm: Accept text’s vimutto against Niddesa’s (a)dhimutto (Cnd 10:22.2). Here, the meditator has already attained the dimension of nothingness, which is the highest of the attainments “with perception” (SN 14.11:5.1). Adhimutta would imply that they are “intent on” realizing the next attainment, as for example MN 105:13.4.

snp5.7:3.5.eng: might they remain there without travelling on?”

snp5.7:4.1.eng: “One free of desire for sensual pleasuress,”

snp5.7:4.3.eng: “depending on nothingness, all else left behind,

snp5.7:4.4.eng: freed in the ultimate liberation of perception:

snp5.7:4.5.eng: they might remain there without travelling on.”

snp5.7:5.1.eng: “If they were to remain there without travelling on,
snp5.7:5.1.comm: In this verse, tiṭṭhe, sītisiyā, and cavetha are all optatives.

snp5.7:5.2.comm: Pūga is explained by the Niddesa as thousands of years or eons, a meaning also found at Pv 42:9.2. The Bhāgavata Purāṇa has varṣa-pūga in the same sense (2.5.34, 4.12.43).

snp5.7:5.3.eng: and, being freed, were to grow cool right there,

snp5.7:5.4.eng: would the consciousness of that sort pass away?”

snp5.7:6.3.comm: Compare the stock idiom saṅkhampi na upeti at eg. SN 20.2:1.7; also Snp 1.12:3.4. Also compare na pamāṇameti at Iti 69:4.3.

snp5.7:6.4.eng: so too, a sage freed from the set of mental phenomena
snp5.7:6.4.comm: Nāmakāya appears here and at DN 15:20.2 meaning the “set” of mental phenomena known as “name”.

snp5.7:7.4.eng: for truly you understand this matter.”

snp5.7:8.3.eng: “They have nothing <j>by which others might describe them.

snp5.7:8.5.eng: eradicated, too, are all ways of speech.”

snp5.8:1.1.eng: “People say there are sages in the world,”

snp5.8:1.4.eng: Is someone called a sage because of their knowledge,

snp5.8:1.5.eng: or because of their way of life?”

snp5.8:2.1.comm: The extraneous variant reading sīlabbatena (not in the Niddesa) appears, oddly, in place of the reciter’s identification of the speaker. The parallel phrase at Snp 4.9:5.1 has it on the next line.

snp5.8:2.3.eng: Those who are sages live far from the crowd, I say,

snp5.8:2.4.eng: untroubled, with no need for hope.”

snp5.8:3.3.eng: “who speak of purity in terms of what is seen or heard,

snp5.8:3.4.eng: or in terms of precepts and vows,

snp5.8:3.6.pli: Kaccissu te bhagavā tattha yatā carantā,

snp5.8:3.7.eng: have they crossed over rebirth and old age, good fellow?

snp5.8:3.8.eng: I ask you, Blessed One; please tell me this.”

snp5.8:4.4.eng: or in terms of precepts and vows,

snp5.8:4.5.eng: or in terms of countless different things.

snp5.8:4.7.eng: they’ve not crossed over rebirth and old age, <j>I declare.”

snp5.8:5.3.eng: “who speak of purity in terms of what is seen or heard,

snp5.8:5.4.eng: or in terms of precepts and vows,

snp5.8:5.5.eng: or in terms of countless different things.

snp5.8:5.6.eng: You say they have not crossed the flood, sage.

snp5.8:5.7.eng: So who then in the world of gods and humans

snp5.8:5.8.eng: has crossed over rebirth and old age, good fellow?

snp5.8:5.9.pli: Pucchāmi taṃ bhagavā brūhi me taṃ”.

snp5.8:6.3.eng: “are shrouded by rebirth and old age.

snp5.8:6.4.pli: Ye sīdha diṭṭhaṃ va sutaṃ mutaṃ vā,

snp5.8:6.6.eng: who have given up all the countless different things.

snp5.8:6.7.eng: Fully understanding craving, they are free of defilements,

snp5.8:6.8.eng: those people, I say, have crossed the flood.”

snp5.9:3.2.eng: for what is seen, heard, thought, or cognized here;
